JavaDoq: KeyValuePair.java   
001 /*

005 package de.general.util;
006 
007 
008 import java.util.*;
009 
010 
011 /**
012  *
013  * @author knauth
014  */
015 public class KeyValuePair<K, V> implements Map.Entry<K,V>
016 {
017 
018     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
019     // Constants
020     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
021 
022     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
023     // Variables
024     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
025 
026     public final K Key;
027     public V Value;
028 
029     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
030     // Constructors
031     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
032 
033     public KeyValuePair(K key, V value)
034     {
035         this.Key = key;
036         this.Value = value;
037     }
038 
039     public KeyValuePair()
040     {
041         this.Key = null;
042         this.Value = null;
043     }
044 
045     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
046     // Methods
047     ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
048 
049     /**
050      * Returns the key corresponding to this entry.
051      *
052      * @return the key corresponding to this entry
053      * @throws IllegalStateException implementations may, but are not
054      *         required to, throw this exception if the entry has been
055      *         removed from the backing map.
056      */
057     public K getKey()
058     {
059         return Key;
060     }
061 
062     /**
063      * Returns the value corresponding to this entry.  If the mapping
064      * has been removed from the backing map (by the iterator's
065      * <tt>remove</tt> operation), the results of this call are undefined.
066      *
067      * @return the value corresponding to this entry
068      * @throws IllegalStateException implementations may, but are not
069      *         required to, throw this exception if the entry has been
070      *         removed from the backing map.
071      */
072     public V getValue()
073     {
074         return Value;
075     }
076 
077     /**
078      * Replaces the value corresponding to this entry with the specified
079      * value (optional operation).  (Writes through to the map.)  The
080      * behavior of this call is undefined if the mapping has already been
081      * removed from the map (by the iterator's <tt>remove</tt> operation).
082      *
083      * @param value new value to be stored in this entry
084      * @return old value corresponding to the entry
085      * @throws UnsupportedOperationException if the <tt>put</tt> operation
086      *         is not supported by the backing map
087      * @throws ClassCastException if the class of the specified value
088      *         prevents it from being stored in the backing map
089      * @throws NullPointerException if the backing map does not permit
090      *         null values, and the specified value is null
091      * @throws IllegalArgumentException if some property of this value
092      *         prevents it from being stored in the backing map
093      * @throws IllegalStateException implementations may, but are not
094      *         required to, throw this exception if the entry has been
095      *         removed from the backing map.
096      */
097     public V setValue(V value)
098     {
099         V old = Value;
100         Value = value;
101         return old;
102     }
103 
104     /**
105      * Compares the specified object with this entry for equality.
106      * Returns <tt>true</tt> if the given object is also a map entry and
107      * the two entries represent the same mapping.  More formally, two
108      * entries <tt>e1</tt> and <tt>e2</tt> represent the same mapping
109      * if<pre>
110      *     (e1.getKey()==null ?
111      *      e2.getKey()==null : e1.getKey().equals(e2.getKey()))  &amp;&amp;
112      *     (e1.getValue()==null ?
113      *      e2.getValue()==null : e1.getValue().equals(e2.getValue()))
114      * </pre>
115      * This ensures that the <tt>equals</tt> method works properly across
116      * different implementations of the <tt>Map.Entry</tt> interface.
117      *
118      * @param o object to be compared for equality with this map entry
119      * @return <tt>true</tt> if the specified object is equal to this map
120      *         entry
121      */
122     @Override
123     public boolean equals(Object o)
124     {
125         if (o instanceof Map.Entry) {
126             Map.Entry e = (Map.Entry)o;
127             Object eKey = e.getKey();
128             if (Key == eKey || (Key != null && Key.equals(eKey))) {
129                 Object eValue = e.getValue();
130                 if (Value == eValue || (Value != null && Value.equals(eValue)))
131                     return true;
132             }
133 
134         }
135         return false;
136     }
137 
138     /**
139      * Returns the hash code value for this map entry.  The hash code
140      * of a map entry <tt>e</tt> is defined to be: <pre>
141      *     (e.getKey()==null   ? 0 : e.getKey().hashCode()) ^
142      *     (e.getValue()==null ? 0 : e.getValue().hashCode())
143      * </pre>
144      * This ensures that <tt>e1.equals(e2)</tt> implies that
145      * <tt>e1.hashCode()==e2.hashCode()</tt> for any two Entries
146      * <tt>e1</tt> and <tt>e2</tt>, as required by the general
147      * contract of <tt>Object.hashCode</tt>.
148      *
149      * @return the hash code value for this map entry
150      * @see Object#hashCode()
151      * @see Object#equals(Object)
152      * @see #equals(Object)
153      */
154     @Override
155     public int hashCode()
156     {
157         return (Key==null   ? 0 : Key.hashCode()) ^
158             (Value==null ? 0 : Value.hashCode());
159     }
160 
161 }
  JavaDoq: KeyValuePair.java
